5220: Shaman en-Kor.author: Moveku
5220: Shaman en-Kor.text_parsed:
I use this one with Daru Spiritualist, Disciple of griselbrand, buried alive and immortal servitude along with a bunch of other 2cmc clerics for fun.

@G-of-G: Redirection of damage does not change its source, so all the redirected damage on the soldier is still dealt by the multiple green creatures. You would need as many Samite Blessing to prevent it all. Its still good to lose only one 1/1 creature tho.

@crashnburn99: There is only one stack. Someone can try to remove the cleric with a spell, but you can continue triggering Daru spiritualist 's ability on top of it on the same stack.

You still need to let the toughness boosting abilities resolve before using Starlit Sanctum 's ability to gain life if you want to gain lots of life.

When you activate Starlit Sanctum 's ability to gain life you must pay for it and sacrificing a cleric is part of that cost.

A payment does not use the stack so the cleric goes to the graveyard right away and its last known infos will be used to determine its toughness when the ability resolves.

You can't respond to a payment, but you can respond to the ability by casting or using an ability to kill the player, or prevent gain of life like skullcrack, or better yet false cure before the ability to gain life resolves.

On the other hand there are spells like devour flesh and condemn that can be used instead of Starlit Sanctum, but the sacrifice or removal effect is not part of the cost, but part of the effect, so you can respond to it by using something to remove the infinitely tough creature before the spell resolves.
5220: Shaman en-Kor.text_posted:
I use this one with [autocard]Daru Spiritualist[/autocard], [autocard]Disciple of griselbrand[/autocard], [autocard]buried alive[/autocard] and [autocard]immortal servitude[/autocard] along with a bunch of other 2cmc clerics for fun.

@G-of-G: Redirection of damage does not change its source, so all the redirected damage on the soldier is still dealt by the multiple green creatures. You would need as many [autocard]Samite Blessing[/autocard] to prevent it all. Its still good to lose only one 1/1 creature tho.

@crashnburn99: There is only one stack. Someone can try to remove the cleric with a spell, but you can continue triggering [autocard]Daru spiritualist[/autocard] 's ability on top of it on the same stack.

You still need to let the toughness boosting abilities resolve before using [autocard]Starlit Sanctum[/autocard] 's ability to gain life if you want to gain lots of life.

When you activate [autocard]Starlit Sanctum[/autocard] 's ability to gain life you must pay for it and sacrificing a cleric is part of that cost.

A payment does not use the stack so the cleric goes to the graveyard right away and its last known infos  will be used to determine its toughness when the ability resolves.

You can't respond to a payment, but you can respond to the ability by casting or using an ability to kill the player, or prevent gain of life like [autocard]skullcrack[/autocard], or better yet [autocard]false cure[/autocard] before the ability to gain life resolves.

On the other hand there are spells like [autocard]devour flesh[/autocard] and [autocard]condemn[/autocard] that can be used instead of [autocard]Starlit Sanctum[/autocard], but the sacrifice or removal effect is not part of the cost, but part of the effect, so you can respond to it by using something to remove the infinitely tough creature before the spell resolves.

5226: Skeleton Scavengers.author: PI314r
5226: Skeleton Scavengers.text_parsed:
@keegan: No where in the rule books (MagicCompRules_20100423.pdf and EN_Magic_Basic_Rulebook_20090710.pdf) does it state that a regeneration shield should always be followed by a death effect on the stack. The basic rule book even implies it is possible to create a regeneration shield prior to a death effect is put on the stack. Thus, one is allowed to activate the regenerate ability when ever one pleases, but the regeneration shields simply are never used within the turn. As the +1/+1 token is part of the activated ability, and not of the regeneration shield resolvement, they are counted!

So, for example: one is allowed to regenerate this creature in the end phase of your oppenent while it still has summoning sickness. if you would have 3 mana (asuming 1 counters still), one can regenerate twice, one costing 1 mana, resulting in two counters, and the second time costing 2 mana, resulting in 3 counters.

(activating it twice for the same mana at interupt speed does not work, because as the first effect on the stack resolves, the later one fizzles as the mana paid was not sufficient)

5226: Skeleton Scavengers.author: superboi
5226: Skeleton Scavengers.text_parsed:
@PI314r: That's how the card would have worked, but it doesn't anymore. Read the oracle wording. it states,
Pay 1 for each +1/+1 counter on Skeleton Scavengers: Regenerate Skeleton Scavengers. When it regenerates this way, put a +1/+1 counter on it.

Also, here's some comments in the FAQ for Stronghold regarding this card.

* Playing Skeleton Scavengers's ability does not put a +1/+1 counter on it right away. Rather, it creates a regeneration shield. If Skeleton Scavengers would be destroyed that turn, instead it uses that shield and regenerates. When that happens, its delayed triggered ability triggers. Only when it resolves is a +1/+1 counter put on Skeleton Scavengers.

* Each instance of the delayed triggered ability is correlated to a specific regeneration shield, and no others. Playing the ability multiple times won't cause multiple +1/+1 counters to be put on Skeleton Scavengers the next time it regenerates.

* The cost to play Skeleton Scavenger's activated ability is determined at the time that ability is played. Once you've paid the cost, a regeneration shield is created. That shield will work even if Skeleton Scavengers gets more +1/+1 counters put on it before it's used.

* The cost to play Skeleton Scavenger's activated ability is determined at the time that ability is played. Once you've paid the cost, a regeneration shield is created. That shield will work even if Skeleton Scavengers gets more +1/+1 counters put on it before it's used.[/spoiler]

5228: Skyshroud Archer.author: Squizzle
5228: Skyshroud Archer.text_parsed:
One of the more memorable and effective pieces of card art I've ever seen. Conventional "rule of thirds" blocking is never an aesthetic bad move. The colors are mindblowing: while the whole piece is done in earth tones, note the subtle distinction of the elf, clad in very "living" colors, with the sickly tones of the environment. The elf has tons of personality: he is hopeful for a better future, stoic in the face of the terrible present, and committed to his purpose. Two-dimensionally, his gaze points toward the hellish skies over the Stronghold, but three-dimensionally, he is looking to some point off-frame and in front of the plane of the foreground. He confronts his situation, but is looking forward, to a better tomorrow--a tomorrow he is going to help make happen, alone if necessary--the sense of isolation in the image is great. He pulls on his bowstring, ready to act...

Mechanically, the card is a decent enough one-drop 1/1. Might interdict an opponent from playing a one-drop of their own if they're only holding one-toughness fliers. The choice of -1/-1 instead of damage is interesting. This archer's arrows hinder their target's ability to act, even as they wound. Very appropriate for the insurgent elves of Rath. Besieged guerrillas must not only attack, but also impair their opponents. Desperation is a mother of innovation.

Magnificent card. Sits alongside Cat Burglar in terms of art quality and flavor/mechanics unity.

5233: Sliver Queen.author: Ferlord
5233: Sliver Queen.text_parsed:
The main reason people use her as a general isn't usually for sliver effects.

I know one regular at my local comic store who uses her, and his deck is just a toy box of good spells and good legendary's.

He doesn't use Mana Echoes. He doesn't use Ashnod's Altar. He doesn't even use Training Grounds.

He doesn't because he already knows that Sliver Queen is amazing, and she doesn't need any help in being amazing. He also thinks it's cheap and lame to do that.

See, sometimes you should play EDH NOT to lose friends. Don't play Ashnod's Altar with Ghave. Don't enchant Curiosity onto Niv-Mizzet. Don't consider Exquisite Blood with Sanguine Bond. Just because you could, doesn't mean you should.

5233: Sliver Queen.author: Kaleidostorm
5233: Sliver Queen.text_parsed:
She's a planeswalker. There's no valid argument against this being the case.

Think about it... There's Sliver Queen, happily clicking and chattering away in her nest, tending to her babies, guarding the legacy artifacts, etc.
Volcano her nest was on erupted. Sliver Queen almost died.
Sliver Queen's traumatic experience ignited her spark, causing her ascension.
Left Rath before the volcano completely killed her.

She's out there... watching, waiting, and now has a spark, meaning she can use extremely powerful magic. It's only a matter of time before she comes out of nowhere with an army of several billion hasted, untargeteable, indestructible, unblockable, and double striking little buggies that can claw their way out of graveyards.

We're doomed. Not even Bolas could handle that ****.

5233: Sliver Queen.author: SirLibraryEater
5233: Sliver Queen.text_parsed:
Step 1: Be an idiot with a Sliver deck.
Step 2: Have 1 copy of each Sliver on the battlefield.
Step 3: Put a token onto the battlefield for {2}.
Here's that token's text box:
Artifact Creature - Sliver
Absorb 1, Defender, Double strike, First strike, Flanking, Flash, Flying, Frenzy 1, Haste, Lifelink, Poisonous 1, Provoke, Reach, Shadow, Shroud, Slivercycling {3}, Trample, Vigilance.
At the beginning of your upkeep, this creature deals 1 damage to you.
This creature can't be countered.
This creature has protection from the color chosen for by Ward Sliver.
This creature can't be blocked except by two or more creatures.
This creature can't be blocked except by Slivers.
This creature gets +1/+1 as long as you control a swamp.
This creature gets +1/+1 for each other Sliver in play.
This creature is colorless. If this creature would be put into a graveyard, you may put it on top of its owner's library instead.
{0}: If this creature is on the battlefield, flip a coin. If you win the flip, exile this creature and return it to the battlefield under its owner's control at the beginning of the next end step. If you lose the flip, sacrifice it.
{1}: This creature's type becomes the creature type of your choice in addition to its other types until end of turn.
{2}: This creature gets +0/+1 until end of turn.
{2}: This creature gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
{2}: This creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.
{2}: Regenerate this creature.
{2}, Tap.gif: Regenerate target Sliver.
{B}: Regenerate this creature.
Pay 2 life: Return this creature to its owner's hand.
{T}: Regenerate target Sliver.
{T}: Target Sliver gets +X/+0 until end of turn, where X is the number of Slivers on the battlefield.
{T}: This creature deals 1 damage to target attacking or blocking creature.
{T}: Target player puts the top card of his or her library into his or her graveyard.
{T}: Tap target permanent.
{T}: This creature deals 2 damage to target creature or player and 3 damage to itself.
{T}: Add one mana of any color to your mana pool.
{T}: Name a card. Target opponent reveals a card at random from his or her hand. If it's the named card, that player discards it. Play this ability only during your turn.
Whenever this creature attacks, it deals 1 damage to target creature or player
Whenever this creature deals damage, you gain that much life.
Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a creature, destroy that creature. It can't be regenerated.
Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a player, you may draw a card.
Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a player, its controller may put a 1/1 colorless Sliver creature token into play.
Whenever this creature becomes blocked, it gets +1/+1 until end of turn for each creature blocking it.
Whenever a creature dealt damage by this creature this turn is put into a graveyard, put a +1/+1 counter on this creature
Whenever this creature is dealt damage, put a +1/+1 counter on it.
Whenever this creature becomes the target of a spell an opponent controls, you may draw a card.
When this creature enters the battlefield, destroy target artifact or enchantment.
When this creature enters the battlefield, you may Fateseal 1.
When this creature enters the battlefield, draw a card.
Sacrifice this creature: Add {B}{B} to your mana pool.
Sacrifice this creature: You gain 3 life.
{1}, Sacrifice this creature: This creature deals 1 damage to target creature or player.
{1}, Sacrifice this creature: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to target player or Sliver.
{1}, Sacrifice this creature: Target Sliver gets +2/+2 until the end of the turn.
{1}, Sacrifice this creature: Each player discard a card.
{2}, Sacrifice this creature: Target player discards a card at random. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.
{2}, Sacrifice this creature: Draw a card.
{2}, Sacrifice this creature: That creature deals 2 damage to target creature or player.
{2}, Sacrifice this creature: You gain 4 life.
{3}, Sacrifice this creature: Destroy target permanent.

104/102

5233: Sliver Queen.author: FarisV
5233: Sliver Queen.text_parsed:
I traded a couple of Mutavaults a while ago for one of these lovely ladies - THE sliver tribal icon. I'm still polishing up my sliver deck and haven't quite gotten her to go infinite yet with any of my several combos (Purphuros, Mana Echoes -which oddly enough I got from a random grab bag from my local store right when I was getting serious about making my slivers, Phyrexian Altar, blur/heart, manaweft/gemhide, etc. she's the queen, combos galore!). Even so, she's still so fun just to put into play and people really do like to see the Queen appear. I always get a little excited when I see her in my hand, and if you're playing slivers right (they're slivers, not hard to do) then by the time you draw or are able to play big mother she should have a decent little welcoming party from her children. Slivers are just so versatile and awesome and sometimes insanely powerful.

Hang on... sorry did I say sometimes? I meant usually. Of course, nothing but a 5/5. What's to dislike? Magic's color spectrum is certainly a humble price for such a well-known and staple card of its history.
I am very happy to have my queen and never get bored showing friends who have never played against slivers before just how quickly they can dominate the board and explode in power.

5235: Soltari Champion.author: BegleOne
5235: Soltari Champion.text_parsed:
Honor of the Pure can go online two turns earlier; it can start boosting power as soon as you cast it on your second turn and attack with your Elite Vanguard. This guy has a CMC of 3 and comes out with summoning sickness, so you can reliably get it to start boosting on the fourth turn. It also doesn't defend against Tremors and Volcanic Fallout like Honor of the Pure does. Nor does this card help while blocking.

But that doesn't mean that it isn't a very good card worthy of consideration in an aggressive white deck, because it's an essentially unblockable creature and white doesn't have many of those.

5236: Spirit en-Kor.author: Lazypete
5236: Spirit en-Kor.text_parsed:
Can someone help here...

My friend played this card then put a pariah on it
( http://gatherer.wizards.com/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=135248 )

So everytime I attacked him he would just let the damage go through and redirect the damage to other creature 1 at a time.

Then he added a Prismatic ward, making damage from green source 0 to this creature.
He then added another one choosing white as its color.
( http://gatherer.wizards.com/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=4150 )

So every time I attacked him, he let all damage pass, then pariah would redirect damage to spirit en-Kor, so green damage was voided, white damage was voided and when I would attack with a black creature he would send the damage to a protection from black knight.

I lost because I emptied my deck.. and I didn't have any destroy enchantment.

Was this good or not?

5236: Spirit en-Kor.author: allmighty_abacus
5236: Spirit en-Kor.text_parsed:
@Lazypete
perfectly legal, next time pack some removal. Creature removal trumps enchant creature removal if you have access to black or red (because if you terminate a pariah in response to your opponent enchanting it, they're down 2 cards and you're only down 1), so keep that in mind.

Also you should always consider running an alternate win condition in every deck, just in case something renders combat ineffective (consider Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth and drain life alongside possibly Cabal Coffer)

5242: Spike Worker.author: Bbone37
5242: Spike Worker.text_parsed: "The crazy thing is that they made such a weak creature cost ." says the person who must not have played during stronghold... Spikes, while not as rage-inducing as Slivers, were a strong type back in the day. The fact that they all had this ability, and could transfer couters between them was great. Add in the fact that many could do things with these counters (see spike feeder), and it made combat very bothersome. Am I saying it was a tier 1 tournement deck? No. But you've got to remember that this was well before the powercreep that we know today. This was, at worst, a grey ogre, with the potential to buff, or be buffed by, another creature. A fine card for the time.

5246: Spitting Hydra.author: Mode
5246: Spitting Hydra.text_parsed:
When i look at Spitting Hydra's artwork, i wonder why the ability costs a +1/+1 counter to activate:
In Magic, +1/+1 counters on a hydra usually represent one head each.
So when you activate the ability to allow the hydra to spit, one head apparently dies in the process.
Yet the head on the artwork doesn't look like the 'regurgitated' acid would have corroded its throat.

@scúmbling1: I wouldn't compare Arc Slogger to the hydra, but there are similarities to Siege-Gang Commander.

Spitting Hyra and Siege-Gang Commander both enter as big body for (the latter divided into a 2/2 and three 1/1s) who can deal damage for and at the cost of shrinking the body (removing a counter / saccing a goblin). When they get flickered or bounced, they are set back to their original strenth and their abilities can be used again.

Arc Slogger might have a big body for , but his ability works different: it allows multiple Shocks for a very low amount of mana without decreasing the slogger's strength, but which can only be used several times per game.

So i agree with AmericanVigor - the idea behind this creature was nice, and despite its rather weak execution, it's nice to see Wizards trying to retry this concept on another card (with success, which is worth mentioning as well, since you know this isn't the only concept that got "a second chance" - especially when fixing from the other side of the power level - sometimes it kind of works, but sometimes it still goes wrong even in the second try.

5252: Tempting Licid.author: eak1801
5252: Tempting Licid.text_parsed: I'm surprised this is only 3 stars. It's not THAT BAD. At it's worst it's a 2/2 for 3, which is passable. It's a reusable lure. It's slightly more slippery than Nemesis Mask. You can make it an enchantment right before you attack, then change it back into a creature after they declare blockers. That's not a 3 star ability in my book. Can't be hit by sorcery speed enchantment hate. And if you're not using it each combat you can keep it untapped to dodge creature hate. This deserves at least 4 stars.

5252: Tempting Licid.author: Mode
5252: Tempting Licid.text_parsed:
Along with Dominating Licid, this is one of the few Licids that doesn't suck.
...In a bad way, i mean.

Most of the other Licids just provide some poor abilities that you'd get from a mediocre 1CC aura, and if you want to keep the Licid in case the enchanted creature dies, you'll have to keep one mana open to end the effect in time. Quickening Licid for example is a 1/1 for 2 mana that can provide first strike.
Seriously, who'd want to pay three mana or even more to switch between this effect and a chump blocker?

Tempting Licid, however, does everything right.
It provides Lure's ability, which is actually worth something, yet also an effect you can't always make use of, so until you can make use of it, you'll still get a bear for three mana.
Additionally since Lure's effect will usually result in the enchanted creature's death (and thus also the loss of this aura), it's very relevant here that you can turn Tempting Licid back into a creature and enchant another creature later.

Assuming that you enchant a creature that all of your opponent's creatures can block,
you could even figuratively go so far to read its ability as:
", , Sacrifice a creature: Attacking creatures are unblockable this turn."

"[i][GG], [T], Sacrifice a creature: Attacking creatures are unblockable this turn.[/i]"

5252: Tempting Licid.author: blurrymadness
5252: Tempting Licid.text_parsed:
Actually, it can't even be hit by instant speed enchant or creature hate unless it's a Vindicate / Mortify or similar. With adequate mana this is a very tough guy to kill sans boardwipes (which, even then, if you ahve a creature who can survive the boardwipe, attach him to them.)

For example, with 4 mana open you can even attach him, dodge naturalize, attach him again, and dodge the creature death.

-Can be used as a reusable blocker
-With untap effects he can be an annoying attacker that you can't kill
-Standard usage of attaching to a saproling and getting and unblockable horde through (also, engulfing slagwurm :D)


Lure effects, especially when they cost {G} (compared to {G}{G}{1}) make for impressive {R}{G} combinations to get your lopsided power guys through (or to kill a whole blob of dudes.)

5261: Volrath's Laboratory.author: Zulp
5261: Volrath's Laboratory.text_parsed: I can see this as being worth it in a tribal deck that had tribe- and color-enhancing enchantments and creatures on the field already. The first thing that comes to mind is Soldiers. If you have two Honor of the Pure, several Veteran Armorsmiths and Swordsmiths, a Field Marshal, and a Captain of the Watch in play, your mana will result in some pretty big tokens, because you can pick color and creature type. The issue is that you have to already be set up for it to really be effective.

5261: Volrath's Laboratory.author: adrian.malacoda
5261: Volrath's Laboratory.text_parsed:
re: ruling

This card was back in the days where certain creature types had intrinsic rules. That means that presumably if you used this to make wall tokens, they could not attack. Similarly, if you used this to make legend tokens, you could only make one. Many cards that had you choose a creature type wouldn't let you choose those two, especially if they affected your opponent's creatures. Presumably they didn't think it didn't make sense thematically to produce walls or legends with this thing.
5261: Volrath's Laboratory.text_posted:
re: ruling

Many cards that had you choose a creature type wouldn't let you choose those two, especially if they affected your opponent's creatures. Presumably they didn't think it didn't make sense thematically to produce walls or legends with this thing.

First, let you tinker with the color/type every time you activate it, instead of just once when you bring it out.  Second, let you tinker with other things about the token... maybe make any power/toughness combination that adds up to 4, for instance.  And/or let you pay more to add various abilities.  There's lots of fun design space here.

5262: Volrath's Shapeshifter.text_parsed: Volrath's Shapeshifter probably has massive potential as a combo card. I could see it used perhaps with a creature that has an ability on the field as well as in the graveyard, or maybe just as a second shot at a giant beatstick; say your opponent feels all warm and fuzzy inside after somehow beating your turn 5 Progenitus, you could sling one of these out and watch as your opponent gets frustrated. The problem with this is that it's inconsistent and would probably need some black graveyard exiling to make sure the creature you want is on top. For this reason, it doesn't make much sense as just a casual addition to a deck. 3.5/5

5262: Volrath's Shapeshifter.author: LordRandomness
5262: Volrath's Shapeshifter.text_parsed:
Volrath's Shapeshifter is a great way to get around attacking drawbacks and even turn them into advantages, since you can transform it mid-combat for cheaps. To illustrate what I mean:

1) Discard Invisible Stalker.
2) Attack with the shapeshifter.
3) Wait until after your opponent declares blockers (oh noes, they couldn't block it!)
4) Discard Rakdos the Defiler.
5) Rakdos connects with effective unblockability and without his first ability triggering.
6) Ouch.

Tricks like that are inordinately difficult to pull off with other shapeshifters, while Volrath's here does it without breaking a sweat. Best of all, a single cast of Disentomb gets you ready to go again, and if you can drop it at instant speed (Quicken, many other flash solutions, any instant speed versions of the effect), you can use it to save your shapeshifter from removal by suddenly making him hexproof! (Although the effect is tricky to use since Disentomb being on top of your 'yard spoils everything: Luckily, there are plenty of "exile target card from a graveyard" once per turn artifacts such as Relic of Progenitus that you should probably be running for the manipulation value anyway)

...*looks at the post below*

Wow. I can't believe I suggested Rakdos instead of Phage. That was kind of silly :p

5262: Volrath's Shapeshifter.author: DarthParallax
5262: Volrath's Shapeshifter.text_parsed:
You know, I think Wizards should maybe be talked into changing their minds about graveyard orders.
Ashen Ghoul is a good example of a card that uses the mechanic badly and isn't really worth the trouble of trying figure out when or how to even make him worth it, let alone try playing the deck against someone, when we have better Black Graveyard Recursion cards in the form of Disentomb and Reanimate and a host of others in between at appropriate points on the power scale.

Skill Borrower, The Mimeoplasm, and Volrath's Shapeshifter though, all do things that are just a bit wonky, and asking specifically 'what is the top card of your graveyard or library' is Design space that I think is worth using to make these slightly offbeat effects more fun. It's kind of like the fun feeling playing Ponder gives you: you get to look at more zones and hold more cards, but really what you are doing is exceedingly simple so even someone just learning the game from an Mxx-Core Set Booster Pack Wars should be able to totally grok and have fun doing it, and I don't see how it would be too complex or slow to perform as a game action in large tournaments the way Sensei's Diving Top is....

5263: Volrath's Stronghold.author: DarthParallax
5263: Volrath's Stronghold.text_parsed:
The most evil decks look at this and use it the way a 'traditional' deck uses Boomerang- save their nasty graveyard with a quick 'bounce' to the library, where it's safe from Tormod's Crypt and Relic of Progenitus, then back to the graveyard it goes next turn!

Not a very common move, but if you always play Tormod's Crypt 'just in case', and you see them Volrath's Stronghold in response to your Crypt....I would be very suspicious of their intentions...

Especially if the target was, you know, an Ichorid, or a Golgari Grave-Troll.

5263: Volrath's Stronghold.author: Sorain
5263: Volrath's Stronghold.text_parsed:
perhaps the single best land I own. Volrath's Stronghold gives you a virtually infinite ability to recur a creature, any creature. Short of exile or eliminating Volrath's Stronghold, no creature in my graveyard will stay there if I don't want it to. Used properly as noted in other posts, it protects against some milling stratgys, and combined with comes into play or cycle effects such as Gempalm Polluter or Twisted Abomination you can repeat effects to nightmarish effect.

I can only thank the design team that this is not 1B Tap, return target creature to your hand. The exploitation that 2 mana return a creature would enable would be horrific.

5264: Walking Dream.author: Fanaticmogg
5264: Walking Dream.text_parsed: This card offers an intersting dichyotomy. On one hand, unblockabililty is good against creature decks, so you might want to find something with a more relevant ability against the decks that are creature-light. On the other, it has a crippling drawback against creature decks. However, there are probably some niches it fits into; for example, against control decks that use a small number of walls, or in a deck with lots of untap effects. At the very least, it's a 3/3 blocker that can beat for an unblockable 3 if you really need it, which could definitely be useful in limited.

Wall of omens is good, but this sucker is also quite nasty. I'll admit, card advantage is nice, but this will benefit you in late game as well as early. This slaps Aggo decks hard as need every little advantage in that those first few turns. Sending back their little two drops makes life difficult on them.

Also, it makes players hesitant to attack.

Usually... Ball lighting

5271: Warrior Angel.author: nunyaJs

It's hard to believe, but at one time I would have given this card 4 stars. I used her in a Tempest block deck with Winds of Rath and Sadistic Glee. Add a little mana ramp with dark rituals and Lotus Petals, and it works(ed) fairly decently. That sort of game plan wouldn't fly today though :(

3.5/5 if for no other reason than the stellar art by Gerald Brom.

5272: Warrior en-Kor.author: kiseki
5272: Warrior en-Kor.text_parsed: The en-kor turn out more powerful than their ability suggests.  They can be difficult to kill, and function like banding on defense.  When you block a large creature with just a kor, you don't kill it, but you spread the damage how you choose.  If they kill the en-kor, you have taken a small loss which can be nothing in comparison to gang blocking a large creature and having your banding creature terrored.  The warrior is my favorite, as I like the Power to Cost ratio to best.  The Nomad is also good and the Outrider should be in any flanking deck.

5274: Youthful Knight.author: Kirbster
5274: Youthful Knight.text_parsed: First hint that this guy is no good... "Youth" means "Inexperienced" means "Juzam Djinn bait." For the same amount of mana, you could play a White Knight, adding an extra point of toughness and protection from black. Or you could play an Order of the White Shield, adding pro-black and a pumpable offense. Either way, these veterans kick the Youthful's Knight's sorry ass 10 ways to Icatia.

5274: Youthful Knight.author: Equinox523
5274: Youthful Knight.text_parsed: Color-shifting is not a new concept, as this is Elvish Archers for white. But this is also an example of how something unique and interesting in one color, can be junk in another. White's 2-drops are some of the best in the game, so this is, even at common, junk by comparison. However, don't underestimate common first strikers in limited - especially multiples on defense. Not horrible, and a decent card for beginners to learn about the game.
